title: Woman’s skull is sliding down her neck – but journey for surgery could kill her
text:
Erin Meegan, 34, is in a race against time to get life-saving surgery (Picture: ErinAid/BPM Media)

A British woman whose skull is sliding down her neck must travel across the world for life-saving treatment – but the flight could be enough to kill her.

Erin Meegan, 34, is bedridden for 20 hours a day after being diagnosed with a host of serious illnesses including craniocervical instability (CCI), which has left her skull sliding down her neck, causing brain stem compression and affecting her breathing, heart rate and temperature control.

She is also fighting Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome, ailments which affect her mobility, sight, memory, speech, heart rate and neck stability.

Erin, who is from East Molesey but moved to Perth, Australia a few years ago, has been offered lifesaving surgery in Barcelona by a renowned neurosurgeon, but needs to raise £55,000 by November 1 in order to pay for the treatment.

She also needs to raise more money to cover travel, accommodation, additional scans and insurances.

Erin is bedridden for 20 hours a day and lives in crippling pain (Picture: ErinAid)

The 34-year-old needs to travel to Barcelona to visit one of the few specialists in the world who is qualified to treat her (Picture: BPM Media)

However, even if she gets the funds on time, the 20 hour flight from Perth to Barcelona could still put enormous pressure on her medical issues, potentially having ‘detrimental’ consequences.

She told Surrey Live: ‘I have terribly blurry vision, and there are days when I cannot look at a screen, or speak, so for the past week I have been blindfolded.

‘I get a lot of pins and needles and get very fatigued very quickly.

‘Sometimes I feel like it would be more humane to take me out the back and shoot me.’

She added: ‘There is no assistance from airlines to fly patients home or provide reduced rates in extreme circumstances.

‘I need a business class ticket because I can’t physically sit for long periods – even take-off and landing will put enormous pressure on me.

Erin says she sometimes feels ‘like it would be more humane to take me out the back and shoot me’ (Picture: ErinAid)

‘The pressure that my skull would put on my spine from sitting up for that amount of time would cause vomiting and fainting and could be detrimental to my heart rate and breathing.’

Erin – who had to have brain surgery when she was 24 after being diagnosed with trigeminal neuralgia – says her conditions have put massive pressure on her husband Isaac, 30, who works full-time alongside caring for her.

Isaac said: ‘I have been deteriorating with my own physical health, and my own mental health, to the point where it is now very difficult to maintain.

The couple are asking the public to contribute ‘in any small way’ so Erin can lead ‘a meaningful life again’.

She wants to complete the final two units of her postgraduate degree, strengthen her body to maintain her other joints and start a family.
